comment.author: 24628996@N00
comment._content: It's Jacobi, not Jaobi, unless the note on the photo itself is incorrect.

comment.author: 11572312@N00
comment._content: George McAneny served in numerous positions in the government of New York City, including president of the Borough of Manhattan (1910-1913), president of the Board of Aldermen (1914-1916), and chairman of the State Transit Commission (1921). This collection consists of lectures, reports, correspondence, committee and association files, clippings, scrapbooks, and photographs, all of which reflect his special interests in regional and city planning, zoning, city and state transit, and city financing. (papers are at Princeton). diglib.princeton.edu/ead/eadGetDoc.xq?id=/ead/mudd/public...

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Thanks for spotting the typo!  It looks like this might be Dr. Abraham Jacobi, founder of pediatric medicine in the U.S., and his son-in-law George McAneny.  What do you think?

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Building suggests they were at the same City College event as www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2368284577/ and www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2422670717/ and more...

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Harry Angstrom and Swang: Thanks for connecting these City College photos and providing a name for the event. We added a subject note, along with Dr. Jacobi's bio.

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Dr. Jacobi's wife was.... also Dr. Jacobi. Mary Corinna Putnam Jacobi (1842-1906), a prominent medical doctor in her own right: www.nlm.nih.gov/changingthefaceofmedicine/physicians/biog...

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: Abraham Jacobi (May 6, 1830 - July 10, 1919) was a pioneer of pediatrics, opening the first children's clinic in the United States. To date, he is the only foreign born president of the American Medical Association. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abraham_Jacobi
